subject: Cybersecurity
title: The Tallinn Manual: Rules of Cyber War
description: A fast breakdown of The Tallinn Manual: Rules of Cyber War for builders.

hook.text: Is a cyber attack an act of war? International law wasn't written for a world where wars are fought with code.

buildup.text: The Tallinn Manual, written by NATO-affiliated experts, tries to apply international law to cyber operations.

discovery.text: Key finding: a cyber attack causing physical damage or death can be treated as an armed attack under international law.

twist.text: But most cyber operations fall below that threshold. Espionage, disruption, and influence operations remain in a.

climax.text: Cyber warfare has outpaced international law. The rules are being written while the war is already being fought.

punchline.text: We're fighting a war whose rules haven't been written.

quiz.question: What does the Tallinn Manual attempt to do?
options: Apply existing international law to cyber operations
Create a new United Nations agency
